questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following would you expect to find? (NEET PG 2021 )

options.label: A
options.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.correct_answer: A. Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Turner Syndrome:
  • • Turner Syndrome:
  • • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO). It presents with several distinct clinical features.
  • • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • • It presents with several distinct clinical features.
  • • Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:
  • • Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:
  • • Short stature : Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom. Primary amenorrhea : Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries). Shield-like chest : Broad chest with widely spaced nipples. Webbed neck : Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck. Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral. Cardiac defects : Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common. Renal anomalies : Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney. Other features : Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.
  • • Short stature : Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • • Short stature
  • • Primary amenorrhea : Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • • Primary amenorrhea
  • • Shield-like chest : Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • • Shield-like chest
  • • Webbed neck : Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • • Webbed neck
  • • Ptosis : Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • • Ptosis
  • • Cardiac defects : Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • • Cardiac defects
  • • Renal anomalies : Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • • Renal anomalies
  • • Other features : Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.
  • • Other features
  • • Ultrasound Findings:
  • • Ultrasound Findings:
  • • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.
  • • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.
  • • streak ovaries
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).
  • • Option B. ECHO shows VSD:
  • • Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.
  • • Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture:
  • • Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.
  • • Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? ( INICET Nov 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient

options.label: B
options.text: Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband

options.label: C
options.text: Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present

options.label: D
options.text: Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.correct_answer: D. Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV , it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.
  • ➤ HPV
  • ➤ avoid sexual intercourse
  • ➤ active lesions
  • ➤ no effective antiviral prophylaxis options
  • ➤ highest during periods
  • ➤ active lesions.
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43
  • ➤ Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318
  • ➤ Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318
  • ➤ Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998
  • ➤ Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

questions.text: A 23y woman who is using the combined oral contraceptive pill misses 2 pills in the 3rd week of the pack. What is the next best step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Take 2 pills the same day and continue

options.label: C
options.text: Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week

questions.correct_answer: B. Take 2 pills the same day and continue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Take 2 pills the same day and continue

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, the missed pill guidelines are –
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Reassure and continue the packet: Simply continuing the packet without taking the missed pills would increase the risk of pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Reassure and continue the packet:
  • • Option C. Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week: This option is more applicable for missing three or more pills, where additional precautions and possibly emergency contraception might be necessary.
  • • Option C. Continue pills and take extra precaution for 1 week:
  • • Option D. Start a new packet immediately: This approach is necessary only when three or more pills are missed in the third week, to avoid a pill-free interval and ensure continued contraceptive protection.
  • • Option D. Start a new packet immediately:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If one or two combined oral contraceptive pills are missed in the third week, the woman should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, then continue the pack as scheduled, taking two pills in one day if necessary. This minimizes the risk of pregnancy.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 15-20 weeks

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Quadruple testing, also known as the quadruple screen or quad screen, is typically performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy, with the most accurate results obtained between 16-18 weeks. The test measures four serum analytes:
  • • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) Unconjugated estriol (uE3) Free Beta-hCG Inhibin-A
  • • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  • • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • • Free Beta-hCG
  • • Inhibin-A
  • • This test helps assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and trisomy 18, as well as neural tube defects. The quad screen has a lower sensitivity compared to the first trimester combined screening (which includes nuchal translucency and dual marker screening), making it particularly useful for women who present for prenatal care later in pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 9-11 weeks : This timeframe is generally used for first trimester screening tests, such as the combined screening, which includes nuchal translucency and the dual marker test (free β-hCG and PAPP-A).
  • • Option A. 9-11 weeks
  • • Option B. 12-14 weeks : This period is also used for the combined first trimester screening but is not appropriate for the quad screen.
  • • Option B. 12-14 weeks
  • • Option D. 22-28 weeks : This period is outside the recommended timeframe for the quad screen. Tests in this period are more focused on gestational diabetes screening and routine ultrasounds.
  • • Option D. 22-28 weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The quadruple test is performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy to screen for chromosomal abnormalities and neural tube defects.
  • ➤ Easy to remember : In Down Syndrome, Beta hCG and Inhibin A are increases (B – Big; B in Beta hCG, B in Inhibin A)
  • ➤ Easy to remember
  • ➤ *King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR. ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin. Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester. Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased. Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy. Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.
  • • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • • Fibrinogen Levels:
  • • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • • ESR:
  • • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • • Platelet Count:
  • • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • • Coagulation Factors:
  • • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • • Clotting Time:
  • • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.
  • • Anti-Thrombin III:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.
  • • Option A. Albumin:
  • • Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.
  • • Option B. Platelet:
  • • Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg59
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg59

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.correct_answer: A. Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea is primarily based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of the rash, with the herald patch and subsequent Christmas tree pattern being hallmark features. Awareness of this pattern and the self-limiting nature of the disease helps in reassuring patients and managing expectations regarding the course of the condition

questions.text: A patient comes after 6 months of vaginal delivery with an episiotomy repair with pain at the site of episiotomy which increases during her periods. On palpation, a nodular lesion is felt. The probable diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scar endometriosis should be suspected when there is cyclic pain and a nodular lesion at the site of an episiotomy or surgical scar, especially if symptoms correlate with menstrual periods.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with a confirmed diagnosis of mild to moderate Alzheimer's dementia has shown aversion and non-compliance to oral medications. The patient's caregiver reports difficulty in administering the oral drugs due to the patient's refusal to swallow pills. Considering the need for continued treatment, which of the following medications could be prescribed in a form that does not require oral administration?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with Alzheimer's dementia who refuses oral medication, rivastigmine can be prescribed in a transdermal patch form, providing an alternative route of administration that ensures the patient can continue to receive their dementia management therapy.

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with prostate cancer is being investigated. The bone scan is reported as a super scan with increased uptake in the bones and reduced activity in the kidney and soft tissue. What is the reason for this super scan appearance? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The super scan appearance is due to increased uptake due to diffuse metastasis.
  • • On a bone scan, a generalized increase in skeletal uptake relative to soft tissue and absent or faint renal activity. This is referred to as a super scan.
  • • All the bones show diffusely increased uptake whereas kidneys are not visualized. Seen with- Metabolic bone diseases Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis
  • • All the bones show diffusely increased uptake whereas kidneys are not visualized.
  • • kidneys
  • • Seen with- Metabolic bone diseases Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis
  • • Metabolic bone diseases Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis
  • • Metabolic bone diseases
  • • Diffuse Sclerotic bone metastasis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Increased uptake by carcinoma prostate: While the primary prostate carcinoma may cause metastases, the increased uptake seen in a super scan specifically refers to bone metastases, not the primary tumor itself.
  • • Option B. Increased uptake by carcinoma prostate:
  • • Option C. Increased uptake by the bone: This option is too general and does not specify the underlying cause, which in the context of a super scan is typically metastatic disease.
  • • Option C. Increased uptake by the bone:
  • • Option D. Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney: This choice misrepresents the scenario, as the decreased visualization of kidneys is a result of the intense skeletal uptake overshadowing other areas, not due to decreased uptake by these organs themselves.
  • • Option D. Decreased uptake by adrenal glands and kidney:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A bone scan super scan appearance in a patient with known malignancy such as prostate cancer usually indicates extensive bone metastasis, necessitating aggressive management and treatment planning to address widespread disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man visits your clinic with his 2-year-old son, expressing concerns about vaccinations due to a belief in his community that vaccinations can lead to impotency. He is fearful for his son's future but is also influenced by societal beliefs. Addressing his concerns requires overcoming which type of barrier? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cultural barrier

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cultural beliefs can significantly influence health decisions, and understanding these beliefs is crucial for effective healthcare communication and intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following are features of Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET MAY 2024) Confabulation Amnesia Peripheral neuropathy Ophthalmoplegia
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy, but not ophthalmoplegia, which is associated with Wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following drug binds to CD4 receptors and is used for both CCR-5 as well as CXCR-4 tropic HIV? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ibalizumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors. After HIV attaches to CD4 via GP120, ibalizumab prevents the conformational change in the CD4 receptor that is necessary for viral entry. Since it acts directly on CD4 receptors, it is effective against both CCR5 and CXCR4-tropic HIV strains.
  • • Entry Inhibitors
  • • Entry Inhibitors
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Maraviroc : This is a CCR5 co-receptor antagonist. It only works against CCR5-tropic HIV and is ineffective against CXCR4-tropic strains.
  • • Option A. Maraviroc
  • • Option C. Fostemsavir: This is an attachment inhibitor that binds to viral GP120, preventing initial attachment to CD4 receptors. It does not bind to CD4 receptors directly.
  • • Option C. Fostemsavir:
  • • Option D. Tenofovir : This is a Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NRTI). It works after viral entry by inhibiting viral DNA synthesis. It does not affect viral entry or bind to CD4 receptors.
  • • Option D. Tenofovir

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ibalizumab is a post-attachment inhibitor that binds to CD4 receptors and prevents HIV from entering T-cells by inhibiting conformational changes required for interaction with CCR5 and CXCR4 co-receptors. It is useful in multidrug-resistant HIV cases where other entry inhibitors like Maraviroc (CCR5-specific) are ineffective.

questions.text: What is the substance used in PET scan? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Fluoro-deoxy-glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Fluoro-deoxy-glucose (FDG) is the primary tracer used in PET (Positron Emission Tomography) scans to image metabolic activity of tissues.

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented lesion on his back. On examination, there is a complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Leprosy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leprosy should be suspected in patients with hypopigmented or erythematous skin lesions accompanied by a loss of sensation, particularly fine touch and temperature. This sensory loss is due to peripheral nerve involvement, which is a characteristic feature of leprosy.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the given ECG? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Torsade’s de pointes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Torsade’s de pointes are a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic twisting pattern.

questions.text: A young male child presented with gum bleeding and bow legs. Which vitamin deficiency is commonly associated with the described features? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ascorbic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gum bleeding and bow legs are seen with Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency.
  • ➤ Gum bleeding and bow legs are seen with Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency.

questions.text: An electron microscopic picture of a cut section of a nerve fiber is given. What is the most commonly affected area in Guillain-Barre syndrome? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Left atrium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. 6th arch

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.
  • ➤ Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve : The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.
  • ➤ Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A patient has Bilateral right sided loss of vision. What is the most likely site of lesion. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Understanding the visual pathway is critical for localizing lesions based on patterns of visual field loss. Lesions at different points along the visual pathway (e.g., optic nerves, chiasma, tracts, or radiations) will produce characteristic visual field defects. This knowledge is used to guide further diagnostic testing and management, which may include imaging studies like MRI or CT scans to visualize the lesion and determine its cause.

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PG analogues

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for adult glaucoma is Prostaglandin Analogues, which are effective in lowering intraocular pressure with a convenient dosing schedule.

questions.text: While discharging a patient who underwent a vesicovaginal fistula repair, which of the following would you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

options.label: B
options.text: Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year

options.label: D
options.text: Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

questions.correct_answer: A. Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sexual abstinence for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma. Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair. The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside. Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing. Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications. Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.
  • • Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a type of urinary fistula that commonly arises due to obstetric trauma.
  • • Small fistulas can heal spontaneously; however, most established fistulas require surgical repair.
  • • The surgical repair is usually performed vaginally after approximately 3 months to allow inflammation to subside.
  • • Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days along with antibiotics is recommended to facilitate healing.
  • • Following VVF repair, it is recommended that the patient abstain from sexual activity for 3 months to allow the surgical site to heal properly and avoid complications.
  • • Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for a year to ensure the integrity and strength of the repair before subjecting the area to the stresses of pregnancy and childbirth.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months : This duration of abstinence is too short for the proper healing of the surgical site. Additionally, avoiding pregnancy for only 6 months might not provide sufficient time for the repair to gain adequate strength.
  • • Option B. Sexual abstinence for 3 weeks and avoid pregnancy for 6 months
  • • Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year : While the recommendation to avoid pregnancy for a year is appropriate, 6 weeks of sexual abstinence may still be insufficient for optimal healing of the fistula repair.
  • • Option C. Sexual abstinence for 6 weeks and avoid pregnancy for a year
  • • Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years : This recommendation is excessively long. While prolonged abstinence can prevent complications, a 6-month period is more than what is typically necessary. Similarly, avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is overly cautious.
  • • Option D. Sexual abstinence for 6 months and avoid pregnancy for 6 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Following vesicovaginal fistula repair, patients should be advised to abstain from sexual activity for 3 months and avoid pregnancy for a year to ensure proper healing and reduce the risk of complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 439, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma , with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • ➤ Mollicutes
  • ➤ Mycoplasma
  • ➤ Ureaplasma
  • ➤ Ureaplasma urealyticum

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum? (INICET MAY 2022) 1. Stellate cells 2. Basket cells 3. Purkinje cells 4. Granular cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 1, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of high fever for 5 days and altered sensorium. On further probing, it was found that he had two seizures one day ago. Peripheral smear shows the following findings. How will you manage this patient? ( INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Clindamycin 600 mg intravenously 8 hourly for 7 days

options.label: C
options.text: Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

questions.correct_answer: C. Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg intravenously at 12 and 24 hours, followed by daily once

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebral malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum is a medical emergency requiring prompt treatment with intravenous artesunate, which is the most effective and rapid-acting medication for severe malaria.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presented to the clinic and underwent karyotyping. What is the likely diagnosis in the karyotype shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, XO karyotype, where there is a complete or partial absence of the second X chromosome, leading to infertility, primary amenorrhea, and other characteristic features.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child presented with fever, fatigue and left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a cardiac biopsy (image shown). Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic myocarditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphocytic myocarditis is indicated by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration in the myocardium and is commonly associated with viral infections. The clinical presentation includes heart failure symptoms, fever, and fatigue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a long-standing history of recurrent abdominal pain, nausea, and steatorrhea. The patient reports a significant history of alcohol abuse, and diagnostic imaging reveals signs of chronic pancreatitis. What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, leading to repeated inflammation, fibrosis, and loss of pancreatic function over time.

questions.text: What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? ( INICET May 2023) 1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute 2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute 3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm 4. Allow chest recoil
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • High-Quality CPR Indicators:
  • • High-Quality CPR Indicators:
  • • 1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.
  • • 1. Chest Compression Rate:
  • • 3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).
  • • 3. Depth of Compression:
  • • 4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.
  • • 4. Chest Recoil:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.
  • • Option A. 2, 3 only:
  • • Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.
  • • Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4:
  • • Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.
  • • Option D. 1 only:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.
  • ➤ Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9 th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46
  • ↳ Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9 th edition page 1509
  • ↳ Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9 th edition page 1509
  • ↳ Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21 st edition 387
  • ↳ Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21 st edition 387

questions.text: Sameer was tried in a court in the case of Sanjay’s murder in the park. Sahil appeared in court and stated that he saw Sameer with an axe in his hand while passing the park. What is this evidence known as? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Indirect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indirect or circumstantial evidence suggests a fact but does not directly prove it. In this case, seeing Sameer with an axe near the park suggests involvement but does not directly prove his guilt.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD complaining of swelling in the neck region, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is the correct treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sistrunk procedure is the definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the excision of the cyst, the entire thyroglossal tract, and part of the hyoid bone to ensure complete removal and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrectly matched? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cystocele - Colposuspension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cystocele, the appropriate surgical management is anterior colporrhaphy, not colposuspension.

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula

options.label: B
options.text: Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: Oral contraceptives act by all of the following mechanisms except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increase GnRH release

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) function through several mechanisms to prevent pregnancy, but increasing the release of Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is not one of them. In fact, OCPs inhibit the release of GnRH.
  • • Mechanisms of action of OCPs:
  • • Mechanisms of action of OCPs:
  • • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum. Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum. Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation. Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.
  • • Inhibit ovulation: By suppressing the release of GnRH, and consequently, the pituitary secretion of Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH), OCPs prevent the development and release of an ovum.
  • • Inhibit ovulation:
  • • Prevent implantation: OCPs create a less favorable endometrial environment for implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • • Prevent implantation:
  • • Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the viscosity of cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and fertilize an ovum.
  • • Cervical mucus thickening:
  • • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia: OCPs cause the endometrial lining to remain thin, which further prevents implantation.
  • • Produce static endometrial hypoplasia:
  • • Affect tubal motility: OCPs can alter the motility of the fallopian tubes, reducing the likelihood of sperm meeting an ovum.
  • • Affect tubal motility:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Inhibit implantation: OCPs prevent the endometrium from becoming suitable for implantation.
  • • Option A. Inhibit implantation:
  • • Option B. Cervical mucus thickening: OCPs increase the thickness of cervical mucus to block sperm penetration.
  • • Option B. Cervical mucus thickening:
  • • Option C. Inhibit ovulation: OCPs suppress the hormonal signals that trigger ovulation.
  • • Option C. Inhibit ovulation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation, preventing implantation, thickening cervical mucus, producing static endometrial hypoplasia, and affecting tubal motility. They do not increase GnRH release; rather, they inhibit it.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition 485
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition 485

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Factor 2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.
  • • Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.
  • • This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Factor 11 : Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.
  • • Option B. Factor 11
  • • Option C. Tissue factor : Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.
  • • Option C. Tissue factor
  • • Option D. Factor 5 : Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.
  • • Option D. Factor 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.
